p: T. capitatum has been treated for a long time to the rank of subspecies of Teucrium polium L. ( T. polium subsp. capitatum). Reassessed over time to a specific rank, it is characterized by emanating a sweet, pleasant odor; it has suffrutics of 8–25 cm densely tomentose, with creeping woody stems and erect branches divided in the inflorescence. The leaves are lanceolate with 3–4 teeth per side and in summer they are revolute. The flowers are gathered in closely spaced verticils to form capituliform inflorescences. T. capitatum has a glaucous color, white or reddish–white corolla and a dense silvery white garment [ 9]. The species was collected in a chalky garrigue, about 700 m above sea level, dominated by the presence of Thymbra capitata (L.) Cav. and often in association with Foeniculum vulgare (Mill.), Euphorbia rigida M. Bieb., Plantago albicans L., Gypsofila arrostoi Guss., Hyparrhenia hirta (L.) Stapf, Diplotaxis harra subsp. crassifolia (Raf.) Maire, etc. T. capitatum grows in all the southern parts of Europe, Middle East up to the Caspian Sea and North Africa.
